question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Put your answer in the box provided and show your work. No credit will
be given for the answer without the correct accompanying work.

1. Find the value of the constant k such that
$\displaystyle u(k,t) = e^{kt}\cos(2x)$ is a solution of the heat
equation $\displaystyle u_{t} = u_{xx}$.
sols:
To determine the constant k such that the equation
$\displaystyle u_{t} = u_{xx}$ holds, we take the appropriate partial
derivatives of the solution $\displaystyle u(x,t) = e^{kt}\cos(2x)$:

\begin{align*}
u_{t}(x,t) &= ke^{kt}\cos(2x) \\
u_{x}(x,t) &= -2e^{kt}\sin(2x) \\
u_{xx}(x,t) &= -4e^{kt}\cos(2x) \\
\end{align*} We then substitute the $\displaystyle u_{t},\,u_{xx}$
terms into the diffusion equation:

\begin{align*}
u_{t} &= u_{xx} \\
ke^{kt}\cos(2x) &= -4e^{kt}\cos(2x)
\end{align*} Cancelling out the $e^{kt}\cos(2x)$ on both sides of the
equation gives us the final answer:

\[{\color{blue} k =-4}.\]
